title: Can quantum-mechanical description of physical reality be considered complete?
text:
Abstract
In a complete theory there is an element corresponding to each element of reality. A sufficient condition for the reality of a physical quantity is the possibility of predicting it with certainty, without disturbing the system. In quantum mechanics in the case of two physical quantities described by non-commuting operators, the knowledge of one precludes the knowledge of the other. Then either (1) the description of reality given by the wave function in quantum mechanics is not complete or (2) these two quantities cannot have simultaneous reality. Consideration of the problem of making predictions concerning a system on the basis of measurements made on another system that had previously interacted with it leads to the result that if (1) is false then (2) is also false. One is thus led to conclude that the description of reality as given by a wave function is not complete.

title: Can quantum-mechanical description of physical reality be considered complete?

title: Jamie Parton, BSc  PhD Researcher  University of Southampton Faculty of Engineering and Physical Sciences International Centre for Ecohydraulics Research
text:
I am a PhD researcher at the University of Southampton’s International Centre for Ecohydraulics Research. I have a deep interest in how we can restore degraded habitats and their ecosystems, and make them more resilient to future shocks, particularly climate change.  My current research is based on monitoring chalk stream restoration - specifically, the Lower Anton Restoration Project. I’m seeking to expand river restoration monitoring to also consider the lateral, vertical, and temporal dimensions in more depth. My work spans from the edge of the floodplain to the riverbed, from the groundwater to the tree canopy, and from macroinvertebrates to macrophytes. 
Post-PhD, I aim to become a postdoctoral researcher. I’m open to conducting a broad range of research, from continuing my work on freshwater ecosystems to researching terrestrial and marine restoration projects.




Ecosystem restoration
Rewilding and nature recovery
Climate change resilience
Pollution mitigation
Interdisciplinary research





PhD in Engineering and the Environment (2024-Present)
BSc in Geography (2021-2024)

title: Jamie Parton
text:
Jamie Parton

Curriculum Vitae

Email: jlp2g21@soton.ac.uk | LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/in/jamieparton



Education


Doctor of Philosophy – Engineering and the Environment | University of Southampton (2024 – Present)


Bachelor of Science – Geography | University of Southampton (2021 – 2024)


Key Skills:



Collecting field research data using diverse equipment including quadrats, clinometers, terrestrial laser scanners, differential GPS stations, and drones.


Communicating research findings through reports, poster presentations, and essays.


Conducting systematic literature reviews.


Analysing geospatial data with ArcGIS and QGIS software.


Analysing samples to produce detailed datasets.



Undergraduate Dissertation | University of Southampton 2023–2024


Title: Plastic Pollution in Beach Sediments at the Mouth of the Exe Estuary, Devon Supervisor: Dr Victoria Dominguez Almela



Produced a literature review, detailing existing knowledge and identifying research gaps.


Organised and carried out a field study, sampling beach sediments at three beaches (20 samples per site, 3 survey repeats).


Processed and analysed 180 samples, documenting 981 collected plastics.


Analysed spatial/temporal variation and key sources/transport mechanisms.


Communicated results through text, charts, tables, maps, and photographs.




Work and Volunteering Experience


Employability Ambassador | School of Geography and Environmental Science, University of Southampton 2023–2024



Coordinated employability events as part of the Events Team.


Hosted a guest speaker event with the Environment Agency.


Produced promotional materials to advertise the talk.



Emergency Department Patient Support Volunteer | Southampton General Hospital, UHS NHS Trust 2023–Present



Supporting patients and staff in the ED Majors area.


Providing refreshments and a listening ear to patients.


Cleaning and stocking waiting rooms and refreshment stations.



Cleaner | Widend Touring Park 2018



Collaborated with staff to clean facilities and maintain the grounds.


Used equipment and chemicals to ensure a safe environment.



Cleaner | Torquay Boys’ Grammar School Sixth Form 2017–2019



Worked with the estates team maintaining tidiness in the sixth form block.




Professional Memberships



Freshwater Biological Association - Student Member


River Restoration Centre - Student Member




References


Dr Lucie Glasheen Teaching Fellow in Human Geography School of Geography and Environmental Science, University of Southampton Undergraduate Personal Academic Tutor Phone: 02380 590238 Email: l.glasheen@soton.ac.uk


Dr Victoria Dominguez Almela Teaching Fellow in Ecology, Geography and Environment School of Geography and Environmental Science, University of Southampton Undergraduate Dissertation Supervisor Phone: 02382 126516 Email: v.dominguez-almela@soton.ac.uk

title: Jamie Parton, BSc  PhD Researcher  University of Southampton Faculty of Engineering and Physical Sciences International Centre for Ecohydraulics Research
text:
I am a PhD researcher at the University of Southampton’s International Centre for Ecohydraulics Research. I have a deep interest in how we can restore degraded habitats and their ecosystems, and make them more resilient to future shocks, particularly climate change.  My current research is based on monitoring chalk stream restoration - specifically, the Lower Anton Restoration Project. I’m seeking to expand river restoration monitoring to also consider the lateral, vertical, and temporal dimensions in more depth. My work spans from the edge of the floodplain to the riverbed, from the groundwater to the tree canopy, and from macroinvertebrates to macrophytes. 
Post-PhD, I aim to become a postdoctoral researcher. I’m open to conducting a broad range of research, from continuing my work on freshwater ecosystems to researching terrestrial and marine restoration projects.

title: Projects
text:
Date: September 2024 – Present
Summary: Investigating the presence and effects of microplastics in freshwater sediments using spectroscopic and microscopic methods.
Details: This project examines microplastic contamination in river sediments, exploring spatial patterns, sources, and potential ecological impacts. We use FTIR, SEM, and machine learning to identify polymer types and predict transport behaviors.




Date: November 2024 – Present
Summary: PhD project studying how restoration of the Anton River supports habitat complexity, hydrological stability, and climate resilience.
Details: This research explores restoration-led changes to the Anton River corridor, focusing on habitat complexity, groundwater interactions, fish refugia, and wetland ecosystem services. Part of a broader investigation into chalk stream restoration science.
